title: Owner of CMX Cinemas Files for Bankruptcy Protection
summary: Miami-based movie theater chain hurt by coronavirus pandemic says it needs concessions from studios and landlords. The owner of theater chain CMX Cinemas has filed for bankruptcy protection, saying it needs breathing room from movie studios and landlords because of the economic crisis triggered by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: White House in Talks to Replace HHS Secretary Alex Azar
summary: Discussions follow criticism of his handling of the Trump administration's early response to the coronavirus pandemic. Administration officials are discussing replacing Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar following criticism of his management of the early response to the coronavirus pandemic, according to six people familiar with the discussions.

title: At Least 13 Public Companies Give Back $170 Million in Small-Business Stimulus Money. Others Say They'll Keep It.
summary: As public companies like Ruth's Chris and AutoNation come under fire for seeking small-business aid, others argue they don't have other resources to keep paying workers. At least 13 of the public companies that received coronavirus hardship loans said they would return the money amid mounting scrutiny, while some of the smaller public companies said they needed the money to keep employees from losing their jobs.

title: Italy to Reopen Gradually Starting on May 4
summary: Coronavirus lockdown to end in stages, with manufacturing and construction to resume first. ROME-Italy announced a timetable for reopening its economy and daily life beginning on May 4, marking a milestone in the hard-hit country's struggle against the coronavirus pandemic.

title: The Doctor Will Zoom You Now
summary: The pandemic lockdown is proof of concept for mass telemedicine.. With most of the U.S. under some kind of directive to stay home, these are boom times for digital doctors. Besides worried patients whose symptoms sound like Covid-19, there are plenty of asthmatics, diabetics and discoverers of alarming rashes who still need prescriptions, even if they're not allowed within two yardsticks of a live physician.

title: Ruth's Chris Political Backlash
summary: Bashing business for following the PPP rules won't help the recovery.. After public criticism Ruth's Chris Steak House, Shake Shack and other restaurant chains are returning loans from the federal Paycheck Protection Program. The economy is still locked down, but already the political backlash against business has begun.

title: Judges Discover a Constitutional Right to Literacy
summary: An appellate ruling opens the door to more judicial legislating.. For an idea of where the legal left wants to go, look at a ruling last week from the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals. The majority of a three-judge panel announced a new constitutional right to state-funded education of a certain quality.

title: A Coronavirus A for Everyone
summary: Pushed by unions, school districts abandon grades for this year.. Here's one for the annals of political opportunism. While students and parents suffer through the pandemic, teachers unions are maneuvering to shelter members from accountability for student performance during the crisis.

title: That Home Away From Home in Virus Times
summary: I wonder how many more fundamental constitutional rights will be violated as localities implement ham-handed measures to address the coronavirus pandemic.. "Tourist Communities Plead With Outsiders to Stay Away" (U.S. News, April 7) likely touched a nerve for many of us who own vacation homes. However well intended the quarantine demand is, the message as delivered damages already delicate relationships between summer homeowners and locals.

title: 'Voter Suppression' and Real Election Facts
summary: Democrats in Georgia use "voter suppression" claims to undermine confidence in the vote, for fearmongering and to raise money.. Regarding your editorial "The 'Voter Suppression' Strategy" (April 15): Georgia is ground zero for fearmongering Democratic claims of "voter suppression." Case in point: Failed gubernatorial candidate Stacey Abrams hasn't yet conceded the 2018 governor's race, which she lost by over 50,000 votes. She claims, without evidence, that her election was stolen and that minority votes were suppressed. In reality, voter turnout jumped by 1.4 million votes over the 2014 midterms-the largest average midterm increase of any state-and statewide turnout was nine points above the national average. African-American voter registration has surged in Georgia.

title: Let's Be Fair About Wages For Our Vital Farmworkers
summary: The richest country in the world wants to cut wages to some of the hardest working people in the country.. I sadly read "White House Seeks to Reduce Pay for Farmworkers" (The Coronavirus Pandemic, April 18). The richest country in the world wants to cut wages to some of the hardest working people in the country. People who are deemed essential for the work they do. The work is so hard that farmers admit they cannot find American citizens who are willing to do the backbreaking work of picking crops. While others speak of giving a bonus to essential workers, our government wants to cut farmworker wages to as low as $8.34 per hour. That is $17,300 annually. I doubt anyone reading this newspaper can conceive of living on that. Yet we think it is fine for the people picking our crops.

title: Is Routine Health Care Now Considered 'Nonessential?'
summary: Can there be a sentient being who doesn't realize that shutting off what once was our medical-care system will cause far more mortality and morbidity than Covid-19?. Kudos for your editorial "Sending Hospitals Into Bankruptcy" (April 20). At last a voice of sanity. However, the problem is much worse and demands action. In essence, the entire U.S. medical-care system, minus Covid-19, has been declared "nonessential." Lifesaving procedures such as open-heart surgery and cancer surgery have been drastically curtailed. Routine medical care for hypertension, diabetes and a host of other serious conditions has, for all practical purposes, been banned.

title: Comments?
summary: Resume Subscription. Letters intended for publication should be emailed to wsj.ltrs@wsj.com. Please include your city, state and telephone number. All letters are subject to editing, and unpublished letters cannot be acknowledged.

title: The Fed Punishes Prudence
summary: Its bailout for risky debt helps investors, not employees.. The Federal Reserve's recent decision to purchase trillions in corporate debt went underreported on Main Street, but shocked credit markets. The move will cushion losses for investors in risky assets, yet it's a dubious step for American capitalism as a whole-one that will accelerate some of the most dangerous trends in the U.S. economy.

title: Do Lockdowns Save Many Lives? In Most Places, the Data Say No
summary: The speed with which officials shuttered the economy appears not to be a factor in Covid deaths.. Do quick shutdowns work to fight the spread of Covid-19? Joe Malchow, Yinon Weiss and I wanted to find out. We set out to quantify how many deaths were caused by delayed shutdown orders on a state-by-state basis.

title: Going to School on the Coronavirus
summary: A Stanford medical student asked for a course on the subject. She got it in days.. Marooned on campus during her spring break in mid-March, Alana O'Mara could easily have slipped into passive despair. Instead, the Stanford medical student saw an opportunity. There was nothing on her syllabus that dealt with the new coronavirus. "I wanted to learn about this thing that has turned the world upside-down," she tells me. "I felt that we, as medical students, needed to study it right away."

title: Notable & Quotable: Wisconsin
summary: 'Rates of new confirmed COVID-19 cases didn't increase in Wisconsin compared with the rest of the country after the April 7 election.'. From "No bump in COVID-19 rates after Wisconsin's April 7 election, study says" in Madison's Wisconsin State Journal, April 25:

title: 'The Soul of an Entrepreneur' Review: Doing It for Themselves
summary: In the 1980s, 20% of Americans were self-employed. By 2016, the number was 10%. What's become of the entrepreneurial spirit?. In the 1980s, two out of 10 Americans worked for themselves. By 2016, that number fell to about one in 10. Who knows how much more it will shrink before the Covid-19 pandemic passes? In "The Soul of an Entrepreneur: Work and Life Beyond the Startup Myth," David Sax speaks up for the many entrepreneurs around the country who have scratched out a living in the shadow of the privileged few, the venture-backed startup founders in Silicon Valley.

title: El Salvador's President Is No Friend of the U.S.
summary: Populist Nayib Bukele uses coronavirus as the pretext to traduce the constitution.. "Just spoke to President Nayib Bukele of El Salvador," President Trump tweeted Friday. "Will be helping them with Ventilators, which are desperately needed. They have worked well with us on immigration at the Southern Border."

title: What Shape Will the Rebound Take?
summary: Don't count on a V-shaped recovery. Up, down, up and then flat is more likely, alas.. For all us former at-home meteorologists turned self-appointed epidemiologists, predicting everything from barely a flu to an epidemic apocalypse of infection rates and ventilator shortages, I've got some good news. As the corona clampdown is (please) coming to an end, there's a new parlor game sweeping the nation. Now, as newly minted armchair economists, we all get to predict the shape and span of the economic recovery. You're in luck: I've got your buzzword-compliant cheat sheet and a few tips, sure to impress your isolation circle and both flatter and flatten their curves.

title: As Kim Jong Un Disappears, North Korea Watchers Advise Caution
summary: The guessing game began when the leader missed his country's most important holiday April 15, then ratcheted higher after a South Korean publication reported he had heart surgery. One question swirled among North Korea watchers this weekend-where is Kim Jong Un?-as the dictator's unexplained absence stretched past two weeks and Twitter lighted up with speculation about his incapacitation or death.

title: Economy Week Ahead: Central Bank Meetings, U.S. Consumer Spending
summary: U.S. gross domestic product is expected to show a contraction for the first quarter of the year. Top economic stories this week will focus on fallout from the coronavirus pandemic and central-bank efforts to respond.

title: MTA Completes Overhaul of L Train's Subway Tunnel
summary: Repairs to a line linking Brooklyn and Manhattan are finished ahead of schedule. A project to repair a New York City subway tunnel connecting Brooklyn and Manhattan has been completed ahead of schedule, despite the coronavirus pandemic, officials said Sunday.

title: New York Schools Prepare for Cuts as Coronavirus Hurts State Revenue
summary: Gov. Andrew Cuomo has warned that state school aid could decline as much as 20%. School districts around New York are struggling to develop budgets for the coming academic year with the prospect of cuts in state aid as a result of the coronavirus crisis.

title: Trump, Putin Statement Stirs Concern Among Some
summary: Rare declaration comes amid U.S.-Russian strains, military tension, disinformation complaints. President Trump issued a symbolic joint statement Saturday with Russian President Vladimir Putin, in a move that has stirred debate within the Trump administration and spawned concern among some lawmakers on Capitol Hill, according to people familiar with the document.

title: America Needs to Win the Coronavirus Vaccine Race
summary: Other countries might not be quick to share. Time to speed up trials and ramp up manufacturing scale.. The first nation to develop a vaccine for Covid-19 could have an economic advantage as well as a tremendous public-health achievement. Doses will be limited initially as suppliers ramp up, and a country will focus on inoculating most of its own population first. Even with extraordinary international collaboration among multiple companies, it could be years before a vaccine is produced at a scale sufficient to help the entire world. The first country to the finish line will be first to restore its economy and global influence. America risks being second.

title: Jackson and Wilson Had Nothing on Trump in an Epidemic
summary: Past presidents, including George Washington, responded to plagues by leaving town and waiting.. Many Americans seem to believe the president should be the country's Principal Public Health Officer, or even Oracle in Chief. Maybe this is because the U.S. relies so much on the executive branch to make government work, or because in times of crisis the president is the natural focus for Americans' anxieties. Whatever the reason, it's new. History reveals that presidents have responded to past epidemics with, well, not much at all.

title: Pentagon Invests in Strategic Metals Mine
summary: U.S.'s sole rare-earths mine must rely on China to process extracted minerals. WASHINGTON-A remote mountain mine in the California desert is poised to get a boost from the Pentagon, which sees the metals it extracts there as vital for national defense-but vulnerable to Chinese dominance over the supply chain.

title: Your Pets Probably Won't Get the New Coronavirus
summary: Veterinary experts say there is little evidence that owners pose a risk to their cats and dogs. Two cats recently became the first pets in the U.S. to test positive for the new coronavirus. But veterinary experts say such cases appear to be extremely rare, and there is little evidence that owners pose a risk to their pets.

title: The Era of Big Government Is...Back
summary: Resume Subscription. History shows that big national shocks have a way of changing the role of government in lasting ways-and any shock as big as the coronavirus pandemic inevitably will alter political life and philosophies in America.

title: People Were Leaving New York City Before. Now What?
summary: Exodus would shrink tax revenue, which would hurt vital services. Ross Sapir's customers are clear when they call to hire a moving van: They are leaving New York City because of the coronavirus crisis and they aren't sure when, or if, they are returning.

title: How Fed Intervention Saved Carnival
summary: The cruise line asked hedge funds for cash before central-bank intervention reopened bond markets. It was mid-March and the vultures were circling Carnival Corp. , the largest cruise-line operator in the world.

title: IRS Recalling Thousands of Workers
summary: Congressmen criticize IRS for asking employees to bring their own masks. WASHINGTON-The Internal Revenue Service is bringing thousands of employees back to agency offices on Monday to deal with a growing backlog of work amid the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Connecticut's Plans to Relocate Patients Recovering From Coronavirus Stir Backlash
summary: Sharon accepts more than 50 people discharged from hospitals in cities like Hartford, Danbury. The rural town of Sharon, Conn., is the state's first test of a plan to relocate older nursing-home residents recovering from the new coronavirus.

title: Zoo Cams Offer Solace for Humans on Lockdown
summary: In a role reversal, it's the people who find themselves caged up. 'I find the seal cam is really nice.'. Devin Madson, a 33-year-old fantasy author, doesn't like feeling caged in her home in the Australian countryside because of the coronavirus lockdown. But she feels better after seeing giraffes wander around a zoo pen.

title: Mnuchin Sees Third-Quarter Rebound for U.S. Economy
summary: Business reopenings should lead to a demand boost, the Treasury secretary says. WASHINGTON-The economy should bounce back in July, August and September as closed businesses resume operations, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said in an interview aired Sunday.

title: Trump's New Arms-Control Envoy Has a Short Clock for an Uphill Deal
summary: Former sanctions chief must try to line up China and Russia for a three-way arms deal before the watershed New START pact expires next year. As President Trump's new special envoy for arms control, Marshall Billingslea faces what many experts say is a nearly impossible mission: negotiating an accord that would cover all Chinese, Russian and American nuclear arms.

title: Pandemic Forces Farmers to Destroy Their Crops
summary: Amid pandemic, orders dry up; 'You don't want to see your crop rot and suffer'. Farmer Carl Grooms has been planning harvests for decades but now he is getting ready to plow under his nearly ripe peppers and beans because there is no market to buy them-and he doesn't want to watch them rot.

title: As Italy Looks to Ease Its Lockdown, Doubts Persist About Its Readiness
summary: South Korea, which was able to largely contain its outbreak, is seen as a model for Western countries. As Italy prepares to phase out its lockdown, many Italians are looking forward to going to the gym, attending church and eating out with friends-the kinds of activities that have already resumed in South Korea, another country that had one of the first big coronavirus outbreaks.

title: China Seeks to Ease Medical Goods Shipment Delays With New Rule
summary: Move could help reduce export delays of face masks, test kits and other critical medical equipment to fight coronavirus. China offered a new route for producers of medical goods to obtain export approval, a move that could help ease recent shipment delays of face masks, test kits and other critical medical equipment to fight coronavirus to the U.S. and other countries.

title: First-Quarter GDP Will Be Bad-With Worse to Come
summary: Wednesday's report will likely show the tip of the iceberg, because more of the economy has been offline in April due to coronavirus shutdowns. The U.S. government is likely to report the country just saw the biggest quarterly economic contraction since early 2009, and forecasters warn the figures will likely provide a preview of worse to come.

title: The Coronavirus Has Made Even Beirut Go Quiet
summary: Many expected the city to take a laid-back attitude about the pandemic; now, army jeeps rumble through the streets at night to enforce a curfew. BEIRUT-Before the coronavirus pandemic, most nights the streets in Beirut's busiest neighborhoods were filled with honking horns, window-rattling bass beats and the shouts of anticorruption activists marching toward Martyrs' Square.

title: Baseball Is Back in Taiwan-With Cardboard Cutouts Instead of Fans
summary: The Chinese Professional Baseball League is one of the only pro sports leagues in the world currently operating. They even have bench-clearing brawls.. It was supposed to be a typical day of work in Taiwan's Chinese Professional Baseball League, but Justin Nicolino couldn't shake the feeling that he was being watched. A pitcher for the Rakuten Monkeys, Nicolino was playing catch in what was supposed to be an empty stadium when the unsettling paranoia struck.

title: Bras That Are Meant to Be Seen
summary: The minimalist bralette is more sleekly sophisticated than risque-and gets dressed up when paired with jackets, cardigans and statement necklaces. Michael Kors Collection bralette, $490, and skirt, $1,290, select Michael Kors stores, Jacquemus jacket, $924, jacquemus.com, Ursa Major earrings, $240, katejones.us, Celine by Hedi Slimane necklace, $790, celine.com

title: How Coronavirus Outmaneuvered France's Health-Care System
summary: Nursing-home residents' deaths of more than 10,000 is one of the highest such tolls of any country world-wide. PARIS-When President Emmanuel Macron entered the Péan nursing home on March 6 to raise public awareness about the dangers coronavirus posed to older people, the French leader brought along a group of officials and journalists.

title: Your Video Therapist Will See You Now
summary: Sessions have gone virtual amid the coronavirus pandemic, raising new challenges. In the weeks since marriage and family therapist Shelley Hanson moved her sessions to video calls because of the Covid-19 pandemic, some of her clients-many of whom are sheltering-in-place with family members-have struggled to find private space to talk. Some couples have hidden out in their cars. A few had therapy from their bedroom closets.

title: Coronavirus Cancels India's Spring Weddings, Spreading Pain Widely
summary: Millions of cooks, artists, servers and entertainers normally earn much of their annual income during the usually frantic spring wedding season. NEW DELHI-The new coronavirus has wreaked havoc on traditional spring weddings, leaving legions of couples the world over disappointed as celebrations are postponed or canceled. Perhaps nowhere has the economic fallout been worse than India.

title: In Another Hit for Farmers, Coronavirus Crashes Ethanol Market
summary: Producers and farmers ratchet back output of fuel made from corn. Plummeting energy demand during the coronavirus pandemic has decimated the ethanol industry. The timing for U.S. farmers couldn't be worse.

title: A Family of Tennis Lovers Rallies, Even Without a Court
summary: A retiree and his grandchildren were itching to keep playing, so they got creative in their driveway and backyard. The tennis courts might be closed, but Zoran Kerezovic's game has never been stronger. The 66-year-old retiree has been rallying regularly with his two grandchildren in the backyard.

title: Tight Airfreight Capacity Will Hamper Post-Coronavirus Recovery, DHL Chief Says
summary: Frank Appel says that despite the turmoil, business will not turn away from globalization. Companies trying to recover from coronavirus-driven lockdowns will face hurdles in shipping markets roiled by deep capacity cuts and weeks of disruptions in global trade, the chief executive of the world's largest logistics company said.

title: Coronavirus Accelerates J.C. Penney's Long March Toward Bankruptcy
summary: Department-store chain faces a tough road to survive bankruptcy and emerge as a viable business. J.C. Penney Co. , battered by missteps and the rise of e-commerce, is on the verge of being done in by the coronavirus.

title: In Anxious Times, Finding Solace in Gardening
summary: To combat the anxiety and cabin fever stirred up by the coronavirus pandemic, many people are finding it therapeutic to work in the soil, plant seeds and watch things grow. Jessica Wallans copes with the anxiety and cabin fever from the coronavirus pandemic by heading outdoors to her vegetable bed.

title: Photos of the Week
summary: Oil tankers stack up off California coast, Georgia reopens businesses amid coronavirus, Iran launches first military satellite and more. Funeral Director Omar Rodriguez inventoried bodies, most bound for cremation, in the main chapel of the Gerard J. Neufeld Funeral Home in Queens, N.Y., on Tuesday. The coronavirus death toll has exceeded the capacity of New York City's four crematories, forcing funeral directors to send hundreds of bodies out of state. Read more.

title: U.S. Military Declares Coronavirus Health Emergency for Troops in Djibouti
summary: The country has registered 986 cases, the highest per capita infection rate in Africa. The head of U.S. forces in East Africa declared a public health emergency for American troops and contractors based in Djibouti on Friday, a move he said would give him greater authority to manage the risk of coronavirus following a sharp spike in cases in the strategically located nation on the Horn of Africa.

title: Investors Buy Up Debt From Stronger Developing Countries
summary: Bond issuance from higher-rated emerging-market economies continues even as investors pull money from riskier nations during the coronavirus crisis. The most creditworthy developing countries have found investors willing to buy their bonds even as the coronavirus pandemic sparked a rush out of emerging markets more broadly.

title: As Coronavirus Cases Climbed, Private-Equity-Owned Hospital Demanded Bailout
summary: Resume Subscription. Pennsylvania's governor was urgently preparing for a surge in Covid-19 cases last month when a private-equity-owned hospital said it would shut its doors unless the state secured a $40 million bailout.

title: Stocks and Oil Send Conflicting Signals
summary: Stocks show anticipation of a quick return to growth, while oil markets price in a longer downturn. Stocks continue to rise despite an unprecedented freeze in global economic activity and an oil-price crash, a divergence that makes some investors skeptical the gains can continue.

title: Firms Try Fewer Products, Build Inventory Amid Coronavirus
summary: Firms have stocked up on raw materials and helped smaller suppliers, but problems keep evolving amid coronavirus. Companies have spent much of 2020 racing to shore up supply chains as the coronavirus shut down much of the world, but business leaders say they expect problems to remain even as countries start to reopen their economies.

title: Texas Hotelier to Keep Money From U.S. Coronavirus-Related Loan Program
summary: Lodging companies affiliated with hotelier Monty Bennett combined have received more than $68 million under Paycheck Protection Program. Lodging companies affiliated with a Dallas businessman that combined have received more than $68 million under a federal aid program say they are keeping the money, despite the government's call for large public companies to return these funds.
